description: 19th century. From French fondant (“melting”), from fondre (“to melt”), from Latin fundere (“to melt”).

entries.meaning: (usually uncountable) A flavored, creamy sugar preparation, used for icing cakes or as a base for candies.
(countable) A candy or cake filled with such a preparation.
examples: At Chapter One, these chocolate fondants are served restaurant-style with a crème brulée ravioli and an unusual basil ice cream as well as the warm sauce given.

entries.meaning: (food) A sugar dough, usually prepared as large sheets (rolled fondant), used in place of icing to cover large areas of cakes, composed of sugar, water, gelatin, glycerine.
examples: Stan made a heroic attempt at a tiered cinnamon cake with a rolled fondant icing that came out gray and tore when he draped it over the cake.

entries.meaning: (usually uncountable) The base or flux, in enamel, which is colored throughout by metallic oxide while in a state of fusion.
(heraldry) Stooping, as for prey: said of an eagle, a falcon, etc.
